content.description: This route has two possible starts; both are hand cracks with face holds on ether side that rise 15 or 20 feet off the deck. If you start on the right (south) side, you can hop over to the left crack about 20 feet up. I believe the right start is easier? Run up the remaining crack to a short chimney and top out.
content.protection:
For TR wrap a boulder up top or build in the crack with cams or large nuts.

For a lead use small and medium cams and medium nuts. Good starter lead!
content.location: This is at the very south end at Duncan's Ridge, just north of the boulder start ".9 wall".

content.description:
Start in the very easy (5.4) crack system below the flake, which takes good gear but honestly isn't needed. Once you reach the flake, pull into the offwidth between the flake and the wall (5.7). Climb the easy but fun offwidth to the top (5.6) for the last 15 feet. This is a great solo, but it can also be led to practice some gear placements. This takes great gear from a #3 to #5 Camalot. The whole route can be done with a #3 and #4/5 very easily.

If you set up a top rope, there is a fun 5.8+ variation of the bottom of the climb. Climb the steep, fairly blank face to the left of the easy crack system at the bottom up until the offwidth.
content.protection: Big gear and a few small pieces for the bottom. A trad anchor can be made at the top for a toprope
content.location:
This is North of the gully but a little south of the

Northern Unnamed

, 5.8-.

content.description: Climb one of two weaknesses in the rock just south of the alternate descent route.
content.protection: Small gear.

content.description: Several variations can be accessed by these anchors. All are 5.7 and below.
content.protection:
Two bolts (without chains). From the ground at the top of the ridge, step down on a little shelf to set the TR anchor.

Gear for lead might be small and sparse.
content.location:
Begin anywhere right of the incut section (

i.e.

, right of

Purdy Dirty

).

content.description:
Begin just right of the

Unnamed Corner

.  Climb to the overhang on good holds.  Reach for the crimps on the crest of the ledge and throw for a higher hand.  Pull over and climb the ladder of good holds to the top.
content.protection: The overhang and the corner to the left can be TR'ed with gear using the same cracks at the top.
content.location:
It is located just right of the

Unnamed Corner

, about 10 yards south of the gully.

content.description: Step up and jam over the first bulge, then follow the obvious corner up and out.  Grab the jugs at the corner exit and let your feet fly!  Angle out right to the top.
content.protection: Solid cracks at the top for a gear anchor.  Lead with small cams and stoppers.
content.location: From the gully, hang against the rocks and head south to the main area - this route will be the first on The Ridge's big face.

content.description:
Maybe somebody has more information. This route is the northern end of the ridge just before the property line and north￼ of

Northern Unnamed

.
content.protection: A 2 bolt anchor.A standard rack will get you up this somewhat improbable lead. The initial moves to the roof are the most difficult to protect, however the climbing isn't too daunting. Watch for the loose flake near the center of the lower face.
content.location: It is 15 yards south of the property line.

content.description: Fire this one move wonder off of the small crimp flake around head height and a low right undercling. Get your feet on, and deadpoint straight to the sharp, conglomerate jug at the lip (which annihilated my hand, so I suggest tape), and top out with an easy mantel.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
Find a small crimp flake on the face directly right of

Rough Hugs

. This is the starting left hand hold.

content.description: This ascends the crack feature right of the Africa Cracks beginning on a positive flake. The topout is somewhat loose. The rest of the climb is good but short.
content.protection: Gear, maybe an extra #2 C4.

content.description: Two Cent is a cool, little climb far away from the main area. It must be climbed at low water. Start on an easy, runout, water polished slab to get to the horizontal break. Place gear, pull the crux over the small roof, and continue on fun moderate slab to the top.
content.protection: An anchor can easily be set with 2s and 3s. Some small to medium cams are useful for a lead.
content.location: This route sits on the far south end of the ridge line just as the rocks head underwater.

content.description:
The route is located through the brush about 100 feet south of the roof route area. It's a prominent hand crack start followed by a short offwidth and tops out on a blocky face.  Start with the nice hand crack (5.7+) for 15 feet to the offwidth.  Enter the offwidth and grunt through (crux) whereupon climbing eases towards the top.

Note that a TR can also be set from above.

A nice and quick intro to hand cracks and offwidths.
content.protection:
Bringa a rack of hand and offwidth size protection. A rack with 1 small set of stoppers/tri-cams for the upper section and anchor is useful.

Per

patrick donahue

: bring a rack from BD c4 #2-#6, and a rack of small nuts for the top is nice.

content.description: This route starts with a high step from a boulder on the ground. Following up and slightly left into a right-facing dihedral, one finds steeper terrain with a placeable crack. Towards the top, step left (watch for loose rock) and finish over a tiny bulge to the top.
content.protection:
For TR, wrap a boulder with 25-30 feet of webbing.

For a lead, small to medium nuts and/or a couple small cams.
content.location: This is about as far south as you want to go at Duncan's Ridge. It is the furthest south route on the wall with bouldering starts, what I call the ".9 wall".

content.description: Avoid the bush by climbing the small cracks on the left side of the wall. Use the jugs to get up into the chimney. It's a short but fun chimney. Use the crack or the crimps on the sides.
content.protection: A standard rack. Save a 0.4, 2, and a small nut for the anchor. You can also wrap the large boulder with a cordalette or webbing.
content.location:
This route is just south of  "

South Corner

".

content.description: Do a low sit start with a big, left hand, flake sidepull with a good heel hook below your hand and a right hand sidepull undercling. Throw right, and compress your way straight up.
content.protection: 1-2 pads are fine.
content.location: It is on the far left of The Mother Boulder. The Mother Boulder is located directly behind a cube-shaped rock that can be seen from the ridge (see the pictures).

content.description:
Go up and over the major roof at Duncan's Ridge. The route is dead center in the middle of the Ridge between the

5.7 Corner

and the

5.9 Dihedral

route.
content.protection:
Bring some long slings for the TR anchors and maybe a tricam or two.

Eds. Per ?Jarrod Keller? &

Daniel Dara

: this route now has a glue-in bolted anchor.

Per

Ryan Nelson

: this had been retrobolted with 6 bolts, but those were removed years ago.

Per

MikeDee Dickinson

: one of the anchor bolts is loose. Back it up!

content.description: Take the crack up, then head right under the roof, and climb over.
content.protection: Trad gear. Bring a sling or cordelette to rap around a horn at the top.
content.location:
This is right of

Roof Route

and

Dihedral Route

.

content.description:
I think the greatness of this route is hidden beneath all the dirt and dust!  Start in the finger seam, then move up to the overhang on finger pockets.  Stem through and head straight up the smooth water groove to an awesome crimp rail.  Exit via either variation of the

Dihedral Route

.  With mileage and cleaning, I think this could be one of the better routes on The Ridge.
content.protection: Use cracks for a gear anchor - same spot as Dihedral.  Could be a run-out lead...tricams and small stuff.
content.location:
This is located in the same cove as

Dihedral

- take the right side instead of the left.

content.description: Start on some jugs, move into the big undercling, and climb the left side of the overhang/arete. The difficulty eases a bit after gaining a large dish. Be prepared for a committing top section.
content.protection: 4-5 pads.
content.location:
This climbs the left side of the arete next to

Liberty's Last Stand

. It starts in the opposite side of the cave as the cave route. Scramble up onto the ledge to get to the landing.

content.description:
Climb the overhang of the Patriot Tower up into the arete. Move up on edges right of the arete and transition left on the face. Once you've successfully transitioned to the face move up on a right hand crimp on the face (left of the arete) and lunge to a deep seem on the far left side.

It is 5.12 when climbing straight up the face near the right arete.

You can bail out left at the top and completely skip the 5.12 crux, making it 5.11-.
content.protection: Use toprope anchors.
content.location: It is on the Patriot Tower.

content.description:
Climb the start of

Apples

, and move right at the break to climb the right face of the wall.
content.protection: Use toprope anchors.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the Upper Wall.

content.description:
Two variations exist. The left variation may go slightly easier than the right.

Left (North) - start to the left of the roof, climb to the undercling/overhang, surmount it (crux), and go left around the arete into a crack. Follow it to the top.

Right (South) - start with a bouldery roof move (crux) into a crack. Continue past some broken, blocky rock into another crack, and follow it to the top.
content.protection: No fixed gear. Small to medium gear. Protect the first move of the right route with a BD #0.4.
content.location:
They are located in the southern portion of DR. From the north, it looks like a nose sticking out.  Start with the bouldery roof moves.

Walk off.

content.description: The crux comes right off the bat: jam through the initial overhang, then hang a right around the boulder.  Pull over a small bulge into a left-facing corner, and either take the finger seam or the nice flake to the top.  This route climbs better than it looks from the ground.
content.protection:
This route will eat everything from a #4 Friend to a #4 stopper, emphasis on small gear.  Plenty of cracks at the top to set up a gear anchor, just watch for a few movable blocks.

NOTE:  If anyone has more info, please add it!
content.location: This route is about 20 yards north of the descent gully, not quite to the property line a bit further up.  You'll know you're there if you see the stuck Metolius TCU in the starting crack.

content.description: Sit start with a big, left hand pinch and a small, right hand crimp. Make a big, right hand move to an undercling slot crack, and continue going up using underclings and maybe a kneebar here and there.
content.protection: 2-3 pads are good.
content.location:
It is located on the right side of The Mother Boulder. The Mother Boulder is located directly behind a cube-shaped rock that can be seen from the ridge (see the pictures).

Per

Daniel McClure

: the GPS coordinates are 40.5326038, -105.1454151.

content.description: This is the full sit start to the Icebreaker, V4. Start matched on a crimpy rail, get a heel hook slap to the right hand crimp, and catch your left hand on a thin undercling.
content.protection: 3 pads.
content.location:
It is in the Duncan's Ridge area past the

roof problem

.

content.description: Start to the right of large crack obvious broken crack. The crux roof is low on the face and will be easy to find. Pull the roof, then continue up the easier face to a good crack that runs to the top of the cliff.
content.protection: Set up a trad anchor in the rocks above.
content.location:
This is the low roof between

Broken Crack

and

Unnamed Overhang

, about 15 right of the start of

Unnamed Overhang

.

content.description: This route is located just to the south of the 5.9 face route on Duncan's Ridge. It is about 35 to 40 feet in height and has a mini-roof about 15 feet up on it. The crux of the route is about three quarter's of the way up the route.
content.protection:
A few hexes and about 25 feet of webbing work pretty well for top roping this route.

This route also had 5 retro-bolts (now removed) to anchor bolts.

Per

James Schroeder

: it can be led (R/X) on gear with cams in shallow horizontal placements for the top section. The rock quality for the placements is dubious.

content.description:
Not to be confused with the Left Nostril, this line starts directly below the same dihedral on the left side of

The Nose

. This route was challenging and varied but seemed no harder than 5.7, so I thought it might be a welcome addition to new climbers.

Start on a rock and step up onto a small sloping shelf directly below a bulge. Work right into a lichen covered open book, and head straight up to the small, blocky overhangs just left of

The Nose

roof. Going left under the first overhang then back right under the second leaves the climber in the left-facing dihedral with a clear line to the top of the ridge.
content.protection:
A toprope anchor can be made a few feet back from the edge of the cliff and easily extended into an obvious, V-shaped notch on the edge in order to avoid rope drag. No gear beyond a standard rack should be necessary for the anchor itself.

Sorry, there are no fixed anchors here.

While the second half of this route could take plenty of gear, the first half is devoid of placements.
content.location:
Find

The Nose

, an obvious feature on the southern cliff band of Duncan's Ridge. Start 6 feet left of here on a rock below a large bulge 12 feet above.

content.description: Start at the bottom of the roof on two underclings, and climb power moves out the roof to a hard crux at the lip. Do a tough mantle, then climb the easy slab (5.4).
content.protection: 3 pads ideal, 2 will work.
content.location:
Park approximately a half mile before the Duncan's Ridge parking lot, at the pulloff right after the "sail sign". This is the same parking spot for the

Sunshine Boulder

. Then walk south along animal trails for a half mile, and the boulder will be on your right, approximately 100 yards up from the reservoir.

content.description: Joe Dirt™ is a decent beginner lead, though somewhat dirty. Positive holds keep you near the line of weakness.
content.protection: A standard rack.

content.description: Start low to the left of the arete, and make moves up the arete on good crimps. The crux is near the top.
content.protection: Two pads or more and a spotter.
content.location: This is the fun part: from the base of Duncan's Ridge, hike north about 300 meters and a bit downhill. GPS: (40.536107, -105.146735).

content.description:
This route is located on upper Duncan's Ridge. It is located about 25 feet to the south of the dihedral route mentioned on this site. There were 2 bolts at the top of this climb, right next to a nice crack. These bolts have since been removed.

To setup a TR anchor, all you need is a few medium hexes and a some tricams.  This route could probably be lead by loaded up on the pro right before the cruxy upper face.

The route begins with 25 feet of 5.5 rock to a small ledge system.  The rock then become smoother with hidden edges.  Follow small edges for 20 feet to the top.  The easy variation is to the right, and the harder variation is to the left.

This route climbs the right dihedral next to the roof route. If you top rope it, watch out for the swing if you slip off the first little overhang. It passes one little overhang, then a second and meanders over to the right up big holds to the top.
content.protection: Bring 15' slings for TR. Use smaller stuff to lead. The added two bolts last summer to the top for lowering. You'll need something to clip them.

content.description: Follow a wide crack up a slab. As it gets steeper, jugs appear on both sides. Hand-traverse right (crux), using awkwardly high but positive feet, into a chimney. Pull around the flake on the left and finish in the handcrack.
content.protection: Gear to 3". If you want to protect the bottom, bring something bigger, but it's pretty easy. Smaller gear (0.5 or so) is useful for the anchor.
content.location:
This is about 15 feet right of

Cave Route

.

content.description: The climb goes up the left corner next to the prominent roof. Follow the crack up for your line. It is a little slabby. The hardest moves are definitely the last 4 feet. It's a tall top rope so have fun.
content.protection: Two bolts were put in at the top last year for lowering, bring something to clip them.

content.description: This is a good climb that involves a few face moves at the bottom and then gets easier near the top. Be aware of a possibility of a slight swing if sharing the anchors with the route to the right.
content.protection:
This route climbs the friction face just left of Dihedral route (5.7). It is easily toproped by sharing the same glue-in bolt anchors as for

B-Route

, which [were] the only fixed anchors on the ridge.

content.description:
Sit start on a good left hand pinch and a small right hand sidepull crimp (the same start as

Mother's Finest

). Make the first two moves of

Mother's Finest

, then traverse left, and top out on the lower part of the boulder.
content.protection: 3-4 pads should suffice.
content.location: Traverse from right to left on The Mother Boulder. The Mother Boulder is located directly behind a cube-shaped rock that can be seen from the ridge (see the pictures).

content.description: SDS on a left hand sidepull and a right hand pinch with your feet on an obvious rail, and then climb straight up the arete to the top.
content.protection: 1 pad at the most.
content.location: This is on the right arete of The Child Boulder. The Child Boulder is located directly left of The Mother Boulder when facing towards Duncan's Ridge (see the pictures).

content.description: This is the first face climb right of the nose routes. Do a V2 boulder problem off the ground to get above the first large roof.
content.protection: Use toprope anchors.
content.location: It is on The Nose Wall.

content.description:
From the start hold 10 feet inside the cave on the left, follow the vertical to overhanging crack/flake system for about 20 feet to a large jug. Using an undercling on the roof, make a reach to a slopey hold and stem up the remaining 10 feet of crack to the top. ***DO NOT USE THE CHOCKSTONES IN THE CRACK.*** They are quite insecure and likely to fall out if used.

For full value on this route, do not use the east side of the cave wall for chimneying/stemming, but stay exclusively to the western overhanging wall until you reach the final crack section.
content.protection:
This route is possible to top rope by putting two or three slings around the large, pedestal-style, rock formation on top of the large pillar. Alternatively, there is opportunity for gear placement throughout the entire route, and it would be possible to climb traditionally.

Eds. Per ?Jarrod Keller?, this now has bolted anchors.
content.location: To find this route, locate the large off-width crack about 50 feet to the south of the roof route. From here, walk around the pillar until you reach a cave-like formation. The start of the route is about 10 feet inside the cave on the left hand side. The start hold is a right hand jug about 7 feet off the ground.

content.description: A steep start with feet on marginal rock leads up to a crack/flake system.
content.protection:
Small gear.

An easy anchor on adjacent horn may make this short climb worth it.

content.description:
This route ascends an obvious crack about 25 feet north of the

Roof Route

. This is a good route for the grade and would make a good beginning trad lead. A few nuts and some medium cams do the trick.
content.protection: There are no bolts at the top, so either use a static climbing rope to trees that are way back or build an anchor with pro in some cracks at the top.

content.description: Start at a finger crack running under about a 10 foot overhang. Climb the crack with decent feet to the top of the overhang, then veer to the left and climb around a small arete. This crack will go up about 10 more feet before splitting in two, take the left crack for the easier variation (about a 5.8) and the right crack for the more difficult variation (5.9). The crux of the route is following the finger crack over the overhang. Try not to use the ledge of a boulder directly behind the top of the overhang, as it makes the route significantly easier. The purest ascent is sticking directly to the face.
content.protection: In the order it was used: #0.5 C4, #9 BD stopper, #1 C4, #3 C4, #8 BD stopper, #0.75 C4. Options for placing gear are plentiful, and anything from a 00 Mastercam to a #4 C4 will work wonderfully.
content.location: Walk south past the main face. Once you get to a point where you can look directly left and see what looks like a walk through under the rocks with a lot of bird shit, you're in front of the cracks. There is absolutely no chalk on the cracks, only lots of bird shit.

content.description: This is a good, short lead. Make initial moves to get into the crack, plug gear, and top out. Use an easy sling anchor.
content.protection: A rack to a #2.

content.description:
Start on

Corner Climb

until it's possible to traverse left, and finish on the upper crack of

Conglomerate Face

.
Climb up on edges and big pockets.
content.protection:
Use glue-in toprope anchor bolts (shared with

Face Route

) for a TR.

Randy Aristotle

adds:

Lead this. Good gear protects the crux moves and it's a short run on positive features to the anchor.
content.location: It is on the right side of the Upper Wall.

content.description:
Right of "

Unnamed Overhang

", a precarious stack of rocks leads to a finish with great position.

Stay on the face left of the death blocks as long as possible.
content.protection: A standard rack.

climbs.name: After Work Romp
climbs.fa: Possibly Josh Bender, Solo, 10/2020, likely earlier - submit an improvement if you know of an earlier ascent.

content.description:
I imagine this has been climbed before, because I'll come here and just climb anything that looks possible. I can only image that over the years other people have had the same approach to this area. Everything is short and pretty easy. If you know anything about this line, please post about it.

This climbs the face/slab to the left of the arete. The route is climber's left of the route '

Unknown North

, 5.7+'. There is a ledge about halfway up the route, and the first 15ish feet of climbing is 5.5 if that. The climbing starts off the ledge and in the corner. It works out right to the arete on thin holds. The "hard" climbing is in the middle of the face, and once you gain the arete, it's pretty much over. You could maybe TR it from the anchors at the top, but it would probably be more of a hassle than it's worth. I enjoyed the climbing and wanted to share it.
content.protection: You may be able to TR it but we did it as a solo.
content.location:
This climbs the face/slab to the left of the arete. The route is climber's left of the route '

Unknown North

, 5.7+'.

content.description: The opening moves to get over the small roof feature are the crux of the route. The middle of the route is a dirty crack line filled with rain washed soil. Protection can be hard to find through this small section, but it is very easy terrain. In the upper section, you will find a finger crack with great protection placements. For building an anchor, top out and use a couple large boulders to the right.
content.protection: Standard rack. Medium hexes help for building the anchor up top.
content.location:
Look for a rock feature that resembles the continent of Africa to the right of

Crackmard

.

climbs.name: Africa's East Coast: aka Noah's Crack

content.description: This is a direct crack line, with a slight overhang at ~10'. It has great hands and sticky feet. This is obvious and awesome. . . it may be the best line ever. It was a brave FA.
content.protection: Nerves of steel and freakish endurance. . . also, may have placed a cam thingy or 3.
content.location:
Within reach of "

Africa's West Coast

". . .a southern reach, it's the direct crack line on the face. It is weird that no person has ever climbed it before us! This was a total FA and a brave one at that!

Certainly it would have been posted (and named) already if another brave soul would've climbed it. . . .
